member.name: T:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl
member.summary: This abstract class can be used to implement a DMO in .NET.

remarks.para: Before attempting to use this class, read the MSDN docs on DMOs! In particular read about IMediaObject, IMediaParamInfo, IMediaParams, and the DMO Wrapper Filter (if you are using DirectShow graphs).

When you read the MSDN docs about creating a DMO, they refer to a template that you can use to make things easier. That template served as the inspiration for this class. To create a DMO, you can just create a class that implements this abstract class, write code for the abstract methods, and you should be good to go.
Here is a more detailed description of the steps you need to take. Note that you can look at the sample code for examples of these steps.

1) Other than ripping out the rather lame logging, you shouldn't need to change any code in IMediaObjectImpl.cs. It is the initial entry point for all the IMediaObject interfaces. It performs parameter checking, makes sure the call is appropriate for the current state, etc. As needed it will make calls to the abstract and virtual methods of the class.
2) Create a class which implements the abstract IMediaObjectImpl class:
3) Generate your own guid so the samples won't interfere with your code: If you are running Dev Studio, go to Tools/Create Guid, choose "Registry Format", click "Copy", then paste into your code.
4) Create the constructor for your class. It must not take any parameters:
remarks.code: public DmoFlip() : base(InputPinCount, OutputPinCount, ParamCount, TimeFormatFlags.Reference)
remarks.para: If you are planning to use this DMO with the DirectShow DMO Wrapper Filter, note that (up to and including DX v9.0) InputPinCount must be 1, and OutputPinCount must be > 0. The ParamCount is the number of parameters your DMO supports, and can be zero. In general, you should use TimeFormatFlags.Reference for the last paramter.

5) Register the parameters your DMO supports using . This must be done in the constructor (unless you have no parameters). Doing this allows you to support IMediaParamInfo and IMediaParams. You will also need to use to find out what parameter value you should use at any given point during the stream. See the docs for these two methods for details.
remarks.code: [ComRegisterFunctionAttribute] static private void DoRegister(Type t) [ComUnregisterFunctionAttribute] static private void UnregisterFunction(Type t)
remarks.para: These tell the OS about your DMO. If you are distributing your code, you will need to make sure they get called during installation (read about RegAsm in the .NET docs). At a minimum, you will need to call DMORegister to register your DMO. See the sample for how this is done.

WARNING: If you use the "Register for COM Interop" compiler switch, the compiler will attempt to register DirectShowLib.dll as well as your DMO. Since DirectShowLib has no registration to perform, this generates an error. That is why the sample uses pre/post build events to perform the registration. You may need to adjust this command for your particular installation.

7) Do everything else. There are 7 abstract methods for which you must write code. These methods are listed in the IMediaObjectImpl Methods page in the Protected Instance Methods section. These methods will contain the information specific to your DMO, and describe what type of data you are willing to process, and perform the actual processing. Note that since the abstract class has verified the parameters, you do not need to re-check them in your implementation. See the descriptions for each method and the sample for details about what each of these methods must do.
You may also need to override some of the 11 virtual methods if their default implementation doesn't match your specific needs. See the documentation for each of these specific methods for details.

If you aren't already knowledgeable about COM and writing multi-threaded apps, this is probably a good time to do a little research. You may have multiple instances of your DMO running in the same process, in multiple processes, called on different threads, etc.

As a simple example of the things you should be thinking of, the logging in (debug builds of) IMediaObjectImpl.cs opens the file as non-sharable. However, if two applications try to instantiate your DMO, the second will fail, solely due to not being able to open the log file. Probably not the desired behavior (told you the logging was lame).

member.name: F:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.ALLPARAMS
member.summary: Used in IMediaParams to specify that an envelope change should be applied to all parameters.

member.summary: COM return code indicating success

member.summary: COM return code indicating method not supported

member.summary: COM return code indicating invalid pointer provided

member.summary: COM return code indicating a method called at an unexpected time

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.GetInputSizeInfo(System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.Int32@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: COM entry point for IMediaObject.GetInputSizeInfo
member.param: Zero-based index of an input stream on the DMO.
Out. Pointer to a variable that receives the minimum size of an input buffer for this stream, in bytes.
Out. Pointer to a variable that receives the maximum amount of data that the DMO will hold for lookahead, in bytes. If the DMO does not perform lookahead on the stream, the value is zero.
Out. Pointer to a variable that receives the required buffer alignment, in bytes. If the input stream has no alignment requirement, the value is 1.
member.remarks: There should be no need to modify or override this method. It will call the abstract and virtual methods to perform its work.

member.summary: COM entry point for IMediaObject.GetOutputSizeInfo
member.param: Zero-based index of an input stream on the DMO.
Out. Pointer to a variable that receives the minimum size of an input buffer for this stream, in bytes.
Out. Pointer to a variable that receives the required buffer alignment, in bytes. If the input stream has no alignment requirement, the value is 1.
member.remarks: There should be no need to modify or override this method. It will call the abstract and virtual methods to perform its work.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.ProcessInput(System.Int32,DirectShowLib.DMO.IMediaBuffer,DirectShowLib.DMO.DMOInputDataBuffer,System.Int64,System.Int64)
member.summary: COM entry point for IMediaObject.ProcessInput
member.param: Zero-based index of an input stream on the DMO.
Pointer to the buffer's IMediaBuffer interface.
Bitwise combination of zero or more flags from the DMO_INPUT_DATA_BUFFER_FLAGS enumeration.

Time stamp that specifies the start time of the data in the buffer. If the buffer has a valid time stamp, set the DMO_INPUT_DATA_BUFFERF_TIME flag in the flags parameter. Otherwise, the DMO ignores this value.
Reference time specifying the duration of the data in the buffer. If this value is valid, set the DMO_INPUT_DATA_BUFFERF_TIMELENGTH flag in the flags parameter. Otherwise, the DMO ignores this value.
member.remarks: There should be no need to modify or override this method. It will call the abstract and virtual methods to perform its work.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.ProcessOutput(DirectShowLib.DMO.DMOProcessOutput,System.Int32,DirectShowLib.DMO.DMOOutputDataBuffer[],System.Int32@)
member.summary: COM entry point for IMediaObject.ProcessOutput
member.param: Bitwise combination of zero or more flags from the DMO_PROCESS_OUTPUT_FLAGS enumeration.
Pointer to an array of DMO_OUTPUT_DATA_BUFFER structures containing the output buffers. Specify the size of the array in the cOutputBufferCount parameter.
Out. Pointer to a variable that receives a reserved value (zero). The application should ignore this value.
member.remarks: There should be no need to modify or override this method. It will call the abstract and virtual methods to perform its work.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.Lock(System.Boolean)
member.summary: COM entry point for IMediaObject.Lock
member.param: Value that specifies whether to acquire or release the lock. If the value is non-zero, a lock is acquired. If the value is zero, the lock is released.
member.remarks: There should be no need to modify or override this method. It will call the abstract and virtual methods to perform its work.

member.summary: COM entry point for IMediaParams.AddEnvelope
member.param: [in] Zero-based index of the parameter, or DWORD_ALLPARAMS to apply the value to every parameter.
[in] Number of segments in the envelope.
[in] Pointer to an array of structures that define the envelope segments. The size of the array is given in the cPoints parameter.
member.remarks: There should be no need to modify or override this method. See and for details about how this works.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.MoCloneMediaType(DirectShowLib.AMMediaType)
member.summary: Make a clone of a media type
member.remarks: Note that like all AMMediaTypes, the clone must be released with DsUtils.FreeAMMediaType when it is no longer needed.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.TypesMatch(DirectShowLib.AMMediaType,DirectShowLib.AMMediaType)
member.summary: Check to see if two Media Types are exactly the same
member.returns: true if types are identical, else false

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.InternalCheckInputType(System.Int32,DirectShowLib.AMMediaType)
member.summary: (Abstract) Determine whether the input stream supports a specific media type
member.returns: S_OK if the specified stream supports the specified media type, else DMOResults.E_InvalidType
member.remarks: This method is called by the abstract class. The implementor should check the properties of the AMMediaType to ensure that if a sample of the specified type is sent, it will be able to process it.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.InternalCheckOutputType(System.Int32,DirectShowLib.AMMediaType)
member.summary: (Abstract) Determine whether the output stream supports a specific media type
member.returns: S_OK if the specified stream supports the specified media type, else DMOResults.E_InvalidType
member.remarks: This method is called by the abstract class. The implementor should check the properties of the AMMediaType to ensure that if requested, it can produce an output sample of the specified type.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.InternalGetOutputSizeInfo(System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: (Abstract) Determine the requirements for the output stream
member.param: The minimum size of an output buffer for this stream, in bytes
The required buffer alignment, in bytes. If the output stream has no alignment requirement, the value is 1.
member.remarks: This method is called by the abstract class. You should never return zero for the alignment.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.InternalFlush
member.summary: (Abstract) Called to flush all pending processing
member.remarks: This method is called by the abstract class. In response, the implementor should discard any pending input buffers.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.InternalProcessInput(System.Int32,DirectShowLib.DMO.IMediaBuffer,DirectShowLib.DMO.DMOInputDataBuffer,System.Int64,System.Int64)
member.summary: (Abstract) Accept input buffers to be processed
member.returns: S_OK if the operation completes successfully, S_FALSE if there is no input to process.
member.remarks: This method is called by the abstract class. It passes the actual data to be process to the implementor. Commonly, the implementor stores these values, waiting for the call to InternalProcessOutput (which contains the buffers into which the results are to be stored), at which point they are released.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.InternalProcessOutput(DirectShowLib.DMO.DMOProcessOutput,System.Int32,DirectShowLib.DMO.DMOOutputDataBuffer[],System.Int32@)
member.summary: (Abstract) Process the input buffers from a previous call to InternalProcessInput into the provided output buffers
member.param: The number of buffers provided (one per output stream)
The output buffer into which the data is processed
member.returns: S_FALSE if there is no output, S_OK for successful operation.
member.remarks: This method is called by the abstract class. It passes the output buffers to the implementor. Typically, this is when the actual work is done, processing the input buffers into the output buffers.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.InternalAcceptingInput(System.Int32)
member.summary: (Abstract) Report whether more input buffers can be accepted
member.returns: S_OK if the implementor is ready to accept an input buffer, else S_FALSE
member.remarks: This method is called by the abstract class. If the implementor has room for another input buffer, it should return S_OK. It is perfectly acceptable for a DMO to only accept one input buffer at a time, and to return S_FALSE until InternalProcessOutput has been called to process the buffer.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.InternalGetCurrentTime
member.summary: (Virtual) Returns the current time in the media stream
member.returns: The current time in the media stream
member.remarks: Typically, this function should be overridden to return the most recent timestamp from the last call to InternalProcessInput. It is used to support IMediaParams.GetParam. The default implementation assumes the stream has no time stamps or that the stream is stopped.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.InternalAllocateStreamingResources
member.summary: (Virtual) Allows stream resources to be allocated
member.remarks: Allows the implementor to allocate any resources necessary for performing the processing. The default implementation assumes we don't need to allocate any addition resources to perform the processing.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.InternalFreeStreamingResources
member.summary: (Virtual) Allows stream resources to be released
member.remarks: Allows the implementor to release any resources used for performing the processing. The default implementation assumes we don't need to release any addition resources.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.InternalGetInputStreamInfo(System.Int32,DirectShowLib.DMO.DMOInputStreamInfo@)
member.summary: (Virtual) Controls information about how input buffers are formatted
member.param: Flags specifying how input buffers need to be formatted
member.remarks: Allows the implementor to specify flags controlling the format of input buffers. The default implementation return FixedSampleSize | SingleSamplePerBuffer | WholeSamples

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.InternalGetOutputStreamInfo(System.Int32,DirectShowLib.DMO.DMOOutputStreamInfo@)
member.summary: (Virtual) Controls information about how output buffers are formatted
member.param: Flags specifying how output buffers need to be formatted
member.remarks: Allows the implementor to specify flags controlling the format of output buffers. The default implementation returns WholeSamples | SingleSamplePerBuffer | FixedSampleSize

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.InternalGetInputType(System.Int32,System.Int32,DirectShowLib.AMMediaType@)
member.summary: (Virtual) Retrieves a preferred media type for a specified input stream
member.param: Index into the array of supported media types
member.returns: DMOResults.E_NoMoreItems if out of range or S_OK for successful completion
member.remarks: If the implementor supports returning a collection of supported media types, it should override this method. The default implementation assumes we don't enumerate our supported types. The app calling this DMO should just try setting something and see if it works.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.InternalGetOutputType(System.Int32,System.Int32,DirectShowLib.AMMediaType@)
member.summary: (Virtual) Retrieves a preferred media type for a specified output stream
member.param: Index into the array of supported media types
member.returns: DMOResults.E_NoMoreItems if out of range or S_OK for successful completion
member.remarks: If the implementor supports returning a collection of supported media types, it should override this method. The default implementation assumes our output type is the same as our input type.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.InternalGetInputSizeInfo(System.Int32,System.Int32@,System.Int32@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: (Virtual) Retrieves the buffer requirements for a specified input stream
member.param: Minimum size of an input buffer for this stream, in bytes
Maximum amount of data that the DMO will hold for lookahead, in bytes
the required buffer alignment, in bytes. If the input stream has no alignment requirement, the value is 1.
member.remarks: The implementator could override this method to specify different values. The default implementation reports that we can accept any alignment, hold no lookahead buffers, and the input buffer must be at least 1 byte long.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.InternalGetInputMaxLatency(System.Int32,System.Int64@)
member.summary: (Virtual) Retrieves the maximum latency on a specified input stream
member.remarks: The latency is the difference between a time stamp on the input stream and the corresponding time stamp on the output stream. The maximum latency is the largest possible difference in the time stamps. The default implementation returns E_NOTIMPL indicating the DMO doesn't support reporting latency.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.InternalSetInputMaxLatency(System.Int32,System.Int64)
member.summary: (Virtual) Set the maximum latency on a specified input stream
member.remarks: The default implementation returns E_NOTIMPL indicating the DMO doesn't support reporting latency.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.InternalDiscontinuity(System.Int32)
member.summary: (Virtual) Called to notify of a stream discontinuity
member.remarks: The default implementation assumes no special processing is required for discontinuities.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.ParamDefine(System.Int32,DirectShowLib.DMO.ParamInfo,System.String)
member.summary: Create a definition for a parameter that is accessible thru IMediaParamInfo and IMediaParams.
member.param: Zero based parameter number to set the definition for
Format string (described in MSDN under IMediaParamInfo::GetParamText)
member.remarks: This method should be called from the constructor of the class that implements IMediaObjectImpl. It defines a single parameter that can be set on the DMO. You must call it once for each of the parameters defined in the call to the IMediaObjectImpl constructor. This allows for automatic support of the IMediaParamInfo and IMediaParams methods. See the for additional details.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.ParamCalcValueForTime(System.Int32,System.Int64)
member.summary: Given a parameter number and a time, return the parameter value at that time.
member.returns: Calculated value for the specified time
member.remarks:
Parameters for DMO can be set in one of two ways. IMediaParams.SetParam can be used to set a parameter to a specific value. It is useful for setting values that aren't intended to change over time. There is also IMediaParams.AddEnvelope. This method can be use for things that change over time. For example, consider a parameter for adjusting the audio volume. You might want to be able to have the volume go from 0% to 150% over the first x seconds.
You can easily support both by using this method. As you prepare to process buffers, take the timestamp that applies to that buffer, and call this method to get the desired value for that parameter at that that time.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.InputTypeSet(System.Int32)
member.summary: Check whether the media type is set for the specified input stream
member.param: Zero based stream number to check
member.returns: true if the stream type is set

member.summary: Check whether the media type is set for the specified output stream

member.returns: true if the stream type is set

member.summary: Get the AMMediaType for the specified Input stream
member.param: The stream to get the media type for
member.returns: The media type for the stream, or null if not set
member.remarks: The abstract class will call to see whether a given media type is supported. To see what media type was actually set, the derived class can call this method.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.OutputType(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the AMMediaType for the specified Output stream
member.param: The stream to get the media type for
member.returns: The media type for the stream, or null if not set
member.remarks: The abstract class will call to see whether a given media type is supported. To see what media type was actually set, the derived class can call this method.

member.returns: The number of bytes that compare as equal. If all bytes compare as equal, the input Length is returned.

member.name: M:DmoBase.IMediaObjectImpl.CatFail(System.Exception)
member.summary: Handle thrown exceptions in a consistent way.

member.name: T:DmoBase.MPEnvelopes
member.summary:
The idea of envelopes (as I understand them) is to allow a parameter value to be applied to a range within the stream. Generally speaking, there is a start time and stop time, a parameter start value and a parameter end value. So, you could say "The volume should go from 0% to 100% over the first 4 seconds." There is also a Curve parameter that controls how quickly the parameter value should change: Linear, Square, Sine, Jump, etc.
Also note, the docs for IMediaParams::FlushEnvelope make no sense to me. Instead of trying to make sense of the crazyness they have written, I have done something simpler. If you flush a range, that range gets set back to the NeutralVal for the parameter.
The assumption (based on comments in IMediaParams::SetTimeFormat) is that the times specified to the envelope are the same format as will be specified to ProcessInput. If you are changing the format, call flush.

member.summary: Add a segment to the envelope. If this segment overlaps other segments, the other segments are deleted or shortened, and this segment is inserted

member.summary: Returns the Envelope the applies to a specific time. Since there is a default segment that covers all possible times, this will always return a value.

member.name: M:DmoBase.MPEnvelopes.CalcValueForTime(System.Int64)
member.summary:
Calculate the parameter value at a specified time
While there are routines written for all the curve types, I'm not enough of a math whiz to feel comfortable that I got it right. I stole the code from elsewhere and converted it to c#, so there's a chance I messed up.
member.returns: MPData value for that time based in the specified Curve

member.summary: Make sure the envelope parameters are valid
member.returns: E_INVALIDARG if parameters are incorrect, else S_OK

member.summary: Count how many bits are set in an flag
member.returns: Count of the number of bits set

member.name: M:DmoBase.MPEnvelopes.DeleteRest(System.Int32,System.Int64)
member.summary: Utility function called from AddEnvelope. When adding an envelope segment, it could happen that the new segment overlaps multiple existing segments. This routine walks starting at the specified segment. It either deletes the segment or adjusts it until it reaches the ending time of the new segment.

member.summary: See if the specified parameter value falls within the allowable range
member.returns: true if the parameter value is valid

member.summary: Updates the given with the new value

member.name: T:DmoBase.ParamClass
member.summary: This class holds all the information about the parameters for this DMO. Using this class allows IMediaObjectImpl to automatically implement IMediaParamInfo and IMediaParams. If your DMO has no parameters, you do not need to create an instance of this class.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the ParamClass class.

member.summary: Defines a new param.
member.param: The zero based index of the param to set.

member.name: P:DmoBase.ParamClass.Parms
member.summary: Gets or sets the param returned to IMediaParamInfo::GetParamInfo

member.name: P:DmoBase.ParamClass.TimeFormats
member.summary: Gets or sets the list of TimeFormats returned to IMediaParamInfo::GetSupportedTimeFormat

member.name: P:DmoBase.ParamClass.CurrentTimeFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets the index into TimeFormats indicating the currently active format

member.name: P:DmoBase.ParamClass.TimeData
member.summary: Gets or sets the TimeData for the current format (see IMediaParams::SetTimeFormat)

member.name: P:DmoBase.ParamClass.ParamText
member.summary: Gets or sets the string text returned from IMediaParamInfo::GetParamText

member.name: P:DmoBase.ParamClass.Envelopes
member.summary: Gets or sets the envelopes holding the parameter info. Note that even if parameter info isn't sent with IMediaParams::AddEnvelope (ie thru IMediaParams::SetParam), this implementation still creates and uses envelopes. It just makes envelopes that span the entire media length.
